lesson.name: Lesson 4.4: Using Function Notation to Describe Rules, Part 1

page.title: 4.4.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will use function notation to describe the rule of a function or how a function behaves at any value of input. In addition, you will represent situations symbolically to solve problems.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain rules of functions when they are written in function notation and create tables and graphs to represent the functions.
  • Write equations that represent the rules of functions.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.4.1: Using Function Notation in Tables of Values
  • 4.4.2: Defining Functions by a Rule
  • 4.4.2: Self Check
  • 4.4.3: Using Tables to Find Function Rules
  • 4.4.3: Self Check
  • 4.4.4: Writing a Rule Using Function Notation

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.4.5: Practice
  • 4.4.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 4.4.1: Using Function Notation in Tables of Values
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Use the tables to answer each question.

\(x\)

\(f(x)=10-2x\)

1

8

1.5

7

5

0

–2

14

\(x\)

\(g(x)=x^3\)

–2

–8

0

0

1

1

3

27


  1. What do you notice?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  • The tables don't say “input” and “output.”
  • While there is a column labeled \(x\), there is not a column labeled \(y\).
  • One function is called \(f\). The other is called \(g\).
  • There’s an expression (rather than a number) on the right side of the equation \(f(x)=10−2x\) and \(g(x)=x^3\).
  • If we substitute the values in the left column for the \(x\) in the expression, we get the values in the right column.


  1. What do you wonder?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  • Why is \(x\) on the right side of the equal sign?
  • Are there rules about how to name functions?
  • What does each equation, \(f(x)=10-2x\) and \(g(x)=x^3\), mean?

page.title: 4.4.2: Defining Functions by a Rule
page.contents:
Activity

Match each equation with a verbal description that represents the same function.

  1. \(𝑓(𝑥)=3𝑥−7\)

Correct! To get the output, multiply the input by 3, then subtract 7 from the result.

Try again.

You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?



  1. \(g(x) =3(x−7)\)

Correct! To get the output, subtract 7 from the input, then multiply the result by 3.

Try again.

You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?



  1. \(h(x)\;=\;\frac x3-7\)

Correct! To get the output, divide the input by 3, and then subtract 7 from the result.

Try again.

You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?



  1. \(h(x)\;=\;\frac x3-7\)

Correct! To get the output, subtract 7 from the input, then divide the result by 3.

Try again.

You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?



  1. For one of the functions, when the input is 6, the output is –3. Which is that function: \(f\), \(g\), \(h\), or \(k\)? Explain how you know.

Correct! g(x), because when x is 6, the expression 3(x−7) has a value of -3.

Try again.

You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?



  1. Which function value \(f(x)\), \(g(x)\), \(h(x)\), or \(k(x)\), is the greatest when the input is 0?
    What about when the input is 10?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

When \(x\) is 0, \(k(x)\) has the greatest value. When \(x\) is 10, \(f(x)\) has the greatest value.



Extending Your Thinking

Mai says \(f(x)\) is always greater than \(g(x)\) for the same value of \(x\). Is this true? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Yes. Here is a possible explanation: Rewrite \(g(x)\) as \(g(x)=3x-21\). Then, to get the output of both functions, we first multiply the input, \(x\), by 3 to get \(3x\), and then we subtract a value from it. For function \(f\), we subtract 7. For function \(g\), we subtract 21. The output of \(g\) will always be 14 less than that of \(f\).

page.title: 4.4.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which function has the least value when \(x =0\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Substitute \(x=0\): \(2(0)+1 =1\). Check all of the functions. One is not the least value. The answer is \(f(x)=2(x-1)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Substitute \(x=0\): \(3(0) = 0\). Check all of the functions. Zero is not the least value. The answer is \(f(x)=2(x-1)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Substitute \(x=0\) and \(2(0-1)=2(-1)=-2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Substitute \(x=0\): \(-4(0)+5 =5\). This is the greatest value, not the least value. The answer is \(f(x)=2(x-1)\).

page.title: 4.4.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Evaluating Functions with Function Notation

Find the Value of a Function
It is very convenient to name a function, and most often we name it \(f\), \(g\), or \(h\). In any function, for each \(x\)-value from the domain we get a corresponding \(y\)-value in the range. For the function \(f\), we write this range value \(y\) as \(f(x)\). This is called function notation, and is read \(f\) of \(x\) or the value of \(f\) at \(x\). In this case, the parentheses do not indicate multiplication.

Function Notation

For the function \(y=f(x)\):

  • \(f\) is the name of the function.
  • \(x\) is the input value.
  • \(f(x)\) is the output value, \(y\), corresponding to the value of \(x\).

We read \(f(x)\) as \(f\) of \(x\) or the value of \(f\) at \(x\).

We call \(x\) the independent variable as it can be any value in the domain. We call \(y\) the dependent variable as its value depends on \(x\).

Independent and Dependent Variables

For the function \(y=f(x)\),

\(x\) is the independent variable as it can be any value.

\(y\) is the dependent variable as its value depends on \(x\).

Much as when you first encountered the variable \(x\), function notation may be rather unsettling. It seems strange because it is new. You will feel more comfortable with the notation as you use it.

Let’s look at the equation \(y=4x-5\). To find the value of \(y\) when \(x=2\), we know to substitute \(x=2\) into the equation and then simplify.

Original Equation

\(y=4x−5\)

Substitute \(x=2\) in for \(x\).

\(y=4(2)-5\)

Simplify.

\(y=3\)

The value of the function at \(x=2\) is 3.

We can do the same thing using function notation. The equation \(y=4x-5\) can be written as \(f(x)=4x-5\). To find the value when \(x=2\), we write:

Original Equation

\(f(x)=4x−5\)

Substitute \(x=2\) in for \(x\).

\(f(2)=4(2)-5\)

Simplify.

\(f(2)=3\)

The value of the function at \(x=2\) is 3.

This process of finding the value of \(f(x)\) for a given value of \(x\) is called evaluating the function.

Try It: Evaluating Functions with Function Notation


Find the value of \(f(x)= 5x + 2\) when \(x = 3\).

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to evaluate a function:

Original Equation

\(f(x)= 5x + 2\)

Substitute \(x=3\) in for \(x\).

\(f(3)= 5(3) + 2\)

Simplify.

\(f(3)=17\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.4.3: Using Tables to Find Function Rules
page.contents:
Activity

  1. A square that has a side length of 9 cm has an area of 81 \(cm^2\). The relationship between the side length and the area of the square is a function.

    For questions a-e use the table by answering each question.

side length (cm)

area (cm2)

1

 a. _______

2

 b. _______

4

 c. _______

6

 d. _______

\(s\)

 e. _______

  1. What is the area in \(cm^2\) when the side length is \(1 cm\)?

Correct! The area is 1 \(cm^2\) when the side length is \(1 cm\).

Try again.

The correct answer is 1. The area is \(1 cm^2\) when the side length is \(1 cm\).



  1. What is the area in \(cm^2\) when the side length is \(2 cm\)?

Correct! The area is 4 \(cm^2\) when the side length is \(2 cm\).

Try again.

The correct answer is 4. The area is \(4 cm^2\) when the side length is \(2 cm\).



  1. What is the area in \(cm^2\) when the side length is \(4 cm\)?

Correct! The area is \(16 cm^2\) when the side length is \(4 cm\).

Try again.

The correct answer is 16. The area is \(16 cm^2\) when the side length is \(4 cm\).



  1. What is the area in \(cm^2\) when the side length is \(6 cm\)?

Correct! The area is \(36 cm^2\) when the side length is \(6 cm\).

Try again.

The correct answer is 36. The area is \(36 cm^2\) when the side length is \(6 cm\).



  1. In your math notebook, write a rule for a function, A, that gives the area of the square in cm2 when the side length is s cm, then click solution to compare your answer.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(A(s)= s^2\)



  1. What does \(A(2)\) represent in this situation? What is its value? Write your answers in your math notebook, then click solution to compare your answer.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(A(2)\) is the area of the square in cm2 when the side length is 2 cm. Its value is 4.




  1. Use the Desmos graphing tool above or technology outside the course.

    Sketch a graph of this function.

Select the Solution button to compare your answer:

Compare your answer:



  1. A roll of paper that is 3 feet wide can be cut to any length.
  1. If we cut a length of 2.5 feet, what is the perimeter of the paper?



    Enter your answer in feet. Use integers only.

Correct! The perimeter of the paper is 11 feet.

Try again.

The correct answer is 11. The perimeter of the paper is 11 feet.



For questions b-f, keep in mind that the roll of paper is 3 feet wide. Complete the table by answering each question.


side length (feet)

perimeter (feet)

1

 a. _______

2

 b. _______

11

 c. _______

\(l\)

 d. _______


  1. If we cut a length of 2.5 feet, what is the perimeter of the paper?

    Enter your answer here. Enter only digits.

Correct! The perimeter is 8 feet when the side length is \(1 cm\) \((1+3+1+3=8)\).

Try again.

The correct answer is 8. The perimeter is 8 feet when the side length is \(1 cm) \((1+3+1+3=8)\).



  1. What is the perimeter in feet when the side length is 2 feet?

    Enter your answer here. Enter only digits.

Correct! The perimeter is 10 feet when the side length is \(2 cm\) \((2+3+2+3=10)\).

Try again.

The correct answer is 10. The perimeter is 10 feet when the side length is \(2 cm\) \((2+3+2+3=10)\).



  1. What is the perimeter in feet when the side length is 6.3 feet?

    Enter your answer here. Enter only digits and decimals.

Correct! The perimeter is 18.6 feet when the side length is \(6.3 cm\) \((6.3+3+6.3+3=18.6)\).

Try again.

The correct answer is 18.6. The perimeter is 18.6 feet when the side length is \(6.3 cm\) \((6.3+3+6.3+3=18.6)\).



  1. What is the perimeter in feet when the side length is 11 feet?

    Enter your answer here. Enter only digits.

Correct! The perimeter is 28 feet when the side length is \(11 cm\) \((11+3+11+3=28)\).

Try again.

The correct answer is 28. The perimeter is 28 feet when the side length is \(11 cm\) \((11+3+11+3=28)\).



  1. In your math notebook, write a rule for a function, P, that gives the perimeter of the paper in feet when the side length in feet is i.

Click solution to compare your answer.

Compare your answers:

\(P(l)=6+2l\)



  1. What does P(11) represent in this situation? What is its value?

Write your answers in your notebook, then click solution to compare your answer.

Compare your answers:

\(P(11)\) is the perimeter of the paper in feet when the paper is cut at a length of 11 feet. Its value is 28




  1. Use the Desmos graphing tool above or technology outside the course.

    Sketch a graph of this function.

Select the solution to compare your answer:

Compare your answers:



Video: Writing Function Rules

Watch the following video to learn more about writing rules with function notation.

page.title: 4.4.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Which function rule can describe the table below?

\(x\)

\(y\)

1

3

2

5

5

11

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When 1 is substituted for \(x\), \((1)+3=4\), not 3. This function does not work for the values. The answer is \(f(x)=2x+1\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: When \(x =1\), \(2(1)+1=3\), when \(x=2\), \(2(2)+1=5\), and when \(x=5\), \(2(5)+1=11\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When 1 is substituted for \(x\), \(2(1)+2=4\), not 3. This function does not work for all values. The answer is \(f(x)=2x+1\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: While this rule works for the first row of the table, when \(x = 2\), \((2)+2=4\), not 5, so the rule does not work for all values in the table. The answer is \(f(x)=2x+1\).

page.title: 4.4.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Write the Function Rule from a Table

Kelly can tune 6 cars in 3 hours. The table below is completed to show this relationship. The last column has the output for any \(x\). This is the rule of the function.

Time spent tuning cars (\(x\))

2

3

6

7

\(x\)

Number of cars tuned up (\(y\))

4

6

12

14

\(2x\)

Kelly can tune 6 cars in 3 hours or 2 cars in 1 hour, so the function rule is \(f(x)=2x\).

Try It: Write the Function Rule from a Table

Determine the rule in function notation for the table below:

\(x\) (input)

1

2

3

4

\(x\)

\(y\) (output)

5

8

11

14

?

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to find the rule in function notation:

In the table, every \(x\) is multiplied by 3, and then 2 is added. The rule is:

\(f(x) = 3x + 2\)


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.4.4: Writing a Rule Using Function Notation
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

  1. Complete the table with the perimeter of a square for each given side length.

side length (inches)

perimeter (inches)

0.5

 a. ______

7

 b. ______

20

 c. ______

a. ______

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

2



b. ______

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

28



c. ______

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

80



  1. Write a rule for a function, \(P\), that gives the perimeter of a square in inches when the side length is \(x\) inches.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(P(x)=4x\)



  1. What is the value of \(P(9.1)\)? What does it tell us about the side length and perimeter of the square?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(P(9.1)=36.4\). It tells us that when the side length of the square is 9.1 inches, the perimeter of the square is 36.4 inches.

page.title: 4.4.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Match each equation with a verbal description that represents the same function.
  1. \(f(x)=2x+4\)

Correct!  To get the output, multiply the input by 2, then add 4 to the result.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is to get the output, multiply the input by 2, then add 4 to the result. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(g(x)=2(x+4) \)

Correct!  To get the output, add 4 to the input, then multiply the result by 2.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is To get the output, add 4 to the input, then multiply the result by 2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(h(x)=4x+2\)

Correct!  To get the output, multiply the input by 4, then add 2 to the result.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is to get the output, multiply the input by 4, then add 2 to the result. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(k(x)=4(x+2)\)

Correct!  To get the output, add 2 to the input, then multiply the result by 4.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is To get the output, add 2 to the input, then multiply the result by 4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Functions A and B are defined by these equations.
    \(A(x)=25+10x\)
    \(B(x)=80-15x\)
    Which function has a greater value when \(x\) is 2.5?

Correct!  Function A has a greater value because B(2.5)=42.5 and A(2.5)=50.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Function A has a greater value because \(B(2.5)=42.5\) and \(A(2.5)=50\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which function is greater when \(x = 4\)?

Correct! \(f(x)=2x -7\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f(x)=2x -7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which function rule describes the table below:

    x

    2

    3

    4

    5

    6

    y

    3

    5

    7

    9

    11

Correct! \(f(x)=2x-1\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.4.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(x)=2x-1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Write a function \(g(x)\) for the following statement: to get the output, subtract 4 from the input, then multiply the result by 2.

Correct! \(g(x)=2(x-4)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.4.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(g(x)=2(x-4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Write a function h(x) for the following statement: to get the output, multiply the input by 5 and then add 2.

Correct! \(h(x)=5x+2\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.4.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(h(x)=5x+2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the value of \(f(x)=−2x−3\) when \(x=2\).

Correct! -7

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Write the rule from the table, then find the value of g(2.5). Enter the integer answer only.

    x

    1

    2

    3

    4

    g(x)

    2

    6

    10

    14

Correct! \(g(x)=4x-2\), \(g(2.5)=8\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(g(x)=4x-2\), \(g(2.5)=8\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.4.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain rules of functions when they are written in function notation and create tables and graphs to represent the functions.
  • Write equations that represent the rules of functions.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.4.1: Using Function Notation in Tables of Values
    • In this activity, you made observations about tables of values that incorporated function notation.
  • 4.4.2: Defining Functions by a Rule
    • In this activity, you matched equations that used function notation to their descriptions. You also compared output values when the same input was entered into different equations.
  • 4.4.2: Self Check
  • 4.4.3: Using Tables to Find Function Rules
    • In this activity, you worked to find function rules for a table of values. You also determined the meaning of values given function notation in the context of the problem. You then sketched a graph of the function.
  • 4.4.3: Self Check
  • 4.4.4: Writing a Rule Using Function Notation
    • In this activity, you wrote a rule from a table of values in function notation. You then used that rule to find other values of the function.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.4.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
